pageMeta.description: Emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) from human activities disturb the radiative energy balance of the earth-atmosphere system. They exacerbate the natural greenhouse effect, leading to temperature changes and other disruption of the earth's climate. Land use changes and forestry also play a role by altering the amount of greenhouse gases captured or released by carbon sinks

While Chile, Ecuador and Mexico experience the largest declines, every country in the region is considered to have “high‑risk” rates of decline. Biodiversity loss reduces ecosystem resilience and increases vulnerability to threats such as the negative impacts of climate change. The LAC region is home to major ecosystems that are directly under pressure because of climate change and other environmental impacts.

Retreating glaciers, bleaching coral reefs or loss of ecosystem services undermine the ability of ecosystems to provide a shield against growing climate‑related risks and creates additional vulnerabilities. Threats against the Amazon rainforest from fires and forest degradation are projected to continue worsening in frequency and intensity (WWF, 2020). Pressures on biodiversity can be physical (e.g. habitat alteration and fragmentation through changes in land use and sea use, and changes in land cover, over-exploitation of natural resources), chemical (toxic contamination, acidification, oil spills, other pollution from human activities) or biological (e.g. alteration of population dynamics and species structure through invasive alien species or the commercial use of wildlife resources), most notably climate change.
The main challenge is to ensure
of biodiversity. This implies strengthening the degree of protection of species, habitats, and terrestrial, marine and other aquatic ecosystems, including oceans (see

). Strategies include eliminating illegal exploitation and trade of endangered species, eliminating illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, putting in place ambitious policy mixes (regulatory approaches, economic instruments, and other information and voluntary approaches); and integrating biodiversity concerns into economic and sectoral policies. Biodiversity preservation and restoration also requires reforming and removing environmentally harmful subsidies and strengthening the role of biodiversity-relevant taxes, fees and charges, as well as other economic instruments such as payments for ecosystem services, biodiversity offsets and tradable permits (such as transferable quotas for fisheries).
Environmental performance can be assessed against domestic objectives and international goals and commitments.
is an integral part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development (New York, September 2015) under
“Protect, restore and promote sustainable use of terrestrial ecosystems, sustainably manage forests, combat desertification, and halt and reverse land degradation and halt biodiversity loss”.

The main international Agreement on biodiversity is the 1992 Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD). Other relevant international agreements are the 1979 Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals, the 1973 Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, and the 1971 Convention on Wetlands of International Importance.

Conference of the Parties (COP15) in Montreal from 7-19 December 2022, where the Post-2020 Biodiversity Framework was discussed, comprising 21 targets and 10 milestones proposed for 2030. Notable targets include the designation of at least 30% of Earth’s land and sea areas as protected for conservation; the reduction of nutrients lost to the environment by at least half, pesticides by at least two thirds, and the elimination of discharge of plastic waste; and the reduction of harmful incentives for biodiversity by at least 50 billion USD per year. The region boasts a wide range of climatic features, including close to 4 million hectares of permanent snow and glaciers, principally located in Chile, Argentina, Peru, and Bolivia; over 4 million hectares of mangroves, in Brazil, Mexico, Cuba, Guyana and Venezuela; and over 70 million hectares of Ramsar-designated wetlands, in Brazil, Bolivia, Mexico, Peru and Argentina (ECLAC, 2020). Crucially, Latin America is home to 23% of the world’s forests, including the Amazon, the world’s largest rain forest which is shared by eight countries.

Between 1990 and 2020, the proportion of regional forest cover decreased from 53% to 46% of the territory (ECLAC, 2020). While most LAC countries suffered a significant net loss, Chile and Costa Rica increased their forest area between 2000 and 2020. After a long period of forest loss last century, Costa Rica implemented recovery and reforestation policies and has managed to increase forest cover replacing land previously used for farming and livestock activities (World Bank, 2022)), forests now reaching almost 60% of the country’s total land area (

). In Chile, with around 25% of forest areas, massive exploitation of primary forests and extensive agricultural areas in places with high rainfall were eroding volcanic soils generating problems of stability and water quality (OECD, 2022).

Policies implemented since 2015 focus on the conservation of natural forests and have encouraged large forest companies to take action in rural development and funding fire prevention which has translated into the recovery of forest land. On average, South America presents the greatest forest cover as a percentage of total land area, averaging 48.9% in 2020 (FAO,2020; ECLAC, 2020). This is driven by countries such as Suriname, Guyana, Brazil, Peru, Colombia, Venezuela and Ecuador, where more than half of land area is covered by forests. Central America presented an average of 45.6%, and the Caribbean an average of 39.7% of forest area (

This pattern is the reverse for arable and cropland area, covering 16.1% of total land area in the Caribbean on average, followed by 15.5% in Central America and 6.5% in South America. Agriculture is an important use of land in Latin America and the Caribbean, providing an average of 7% value added to LAC economies, as a proportion of GDP, baring greater importance in Central America, and lesser in South America (OECD, 2022). The region contains around 650 million hectares of agricultural area, including meadows and pastures, arable land and permanent crops, of which Brazil counts with the largest, with close to 237 million hectares, followed by Argentina, Mexico, Colombia, Bolivia, Peru, Venezuela, and Uruguay. Countries with high proportions of agricultural area under organic agriculture relative to the region include Uruguay (19.5% in 2020), French Guiana (11.3%), Dominican Republic (4.8%) and Argentina (4.1%). Transformative actions to continue to reform land use policies will need to take into account the central role agricultural systems to the LAC economies and societies, representing an important source of income, employment and food for the region and the world (ECLAC, 2021).

Protected areas are legally designated areas for the protection and maintenance of biological diversity and of natural resources and the associated cultural resources, managed through administrative or other effective means. Although national classifications differ, The International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has developed an internationally agreed definition of protected areas, which classify them as nature reserves and wilderness areas, national parks, natural monuments, habitat or species management areas, protected landscapes or seascapes, and protected areas with sustainable use of natural resources.

Conference of the Parties of the Convention on Biological Diversity discussed the Post-2020 Biodiversity Framework, including a target designating at least 30% of Earth’s land and sea areas as protected for conservation by 2030. The LAC region as a whole is close to reaching this target, with an average of 29.7% of land designated as terrestrial protected areas (

). This share has increased steadily over the past few decades from an average of under 3% across the region in 1970, to under 5% in 1980, to just under 30%, the CBD 2030 target, in 2021. Countries driving the trend include Belize, Bolivia, Brazil, Guatemala, Nicaragua, Panama, Trinidad and Tobago and Venezuela, all of which have surpassed the CBD 2030 target. Nevertheless, most of these countries rely on the least stringent category of protected areas (protected landscapes) rather than strict nature reserves, national parks and wilderness areas. Taking the latter category alone, no LAC country would meet the CBD target, meaning there is scope for further protection of terrestrial biodiversity.
Source: OECD, “Biodiversity: Protected areas”, OECD Environment Statistics (database),

Data on protected areas is available for most LAC countries. The definitions, although harmonised by the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, may vary among countries. The extent, and management types, of terrestrial and marine protected areas can indicate countries’ efforts to safeguard habitats and species as well as landscapes shaped by human-environment interactions that are valued for cultural or other reasons. Protected areas are not always representative of national biodiversity or sufficiently connected. Indicators on the extent of protected areas do not reflect the effectiveness of the management of these areas.
